_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. Executive Summary



This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR ?68

- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR ?5189

- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR ?1910.119



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.



This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Delta Packing has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 



1.1 Delta Packing, Risk and Process Safety Management Program



This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Delta Packing has updated and consolidated their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following processes which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 



Process Name                         | Process Chemical          | Process Quantity(lbs.)

North Ammonia Refrigeration System     Anhydrous Ammonia           28,000



Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses, and physical property damage.



Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 

1. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM regulation

to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well

2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices

3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)



The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures, and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.



1.2 Process Descriptions



Delta Packing operates a cherry processing facility in Lodi, CA. The facility has three (3) ammonia refrigeration systems that provide refrigeration capacity to the following:



North System (6021 E Kettleman Ln, Lodi, CA 95240)

(5) Cold Storage Rooms

(5) Precool Rooms

(1) Hallway

(4) Hydrocoolers



The refrigerated spaces are equipped with air-cooling evaporators and accumulators as required for flooded operation.



Most control valve groups are located on the roof to provide easy access. The refrigeration machinery is contained within or directly above each machinery room. A partial list of the systems components includes:



North System



The North System is located at 6021 E Kettleman Ln, Lodi, CA 95240 and was originally built in 1979. Initially, the system had a single machinery room on the south side of building which provided refrigeration to five cold rooms and the hallway. In 2012, Industrial Refrigeration Services was hired to install a second machinery room, a cold storage room, and five (5) precool rooms.

The system operates as follows: high pressure liquid from the high pressure receiver is piped to each cold room and hydrocooler, where it passes through an expansion valve into low temperature and pressure accumulator. From the accumulator, low pressure liquid is circulated through evaporator coils. As heat is absorbed, the liquid ammonia vaporizes to form low temperature and pressure gas which is returned to the accumulator. The suction gas is returned from the accumulators through a suction return line to a main suction accumulator. From the main suction accumulator, ammonia is piped to the suction inlet on the compressors. The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to water-cooled evaporative condensers where the high pressure gas ammonia is cooled, liquefied and returned to the high pressure receiver.



The system contain numerous safety devices including sensors which stop the compressors if temperatures or pressur

es exceed or drop below established limits, and pressure relief valves which vent to a diffusion tank if the pressure in the systems exceeds their set point. Each machinery room is equipped with an emergency control box, mounted to the exterior wall of the room which contains three valves. The high and low side of the system each have a valve that would discharge to the diffusion tank. The connecting pipe between the high and low side has one equalizer valve that would equalize the system. Ammonia detectors are installed throughout the facilities in machinery rooms and non-machinery rooms that contain ammonia equipment.



RAGAGEP Statement

The refrigeration system was analyzed during the 2018 Mechanical Integrity Audit (MIA) and Code Compliance Inspection to determine which codes and standards were following during the design and construction of the system. It is unknown which codes and standards were used, but in the judgment of the engineer who performed the MIA, the following is true:

 

1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



1.3.1 General 



We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.



Delta Packing has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration processes. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 



1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia

The ammonia refrigeration process at the Delta Packing facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that emp

loyees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.



Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep active records of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 



1.4 Five Year Accident History



Delta Packing has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.



1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan



Delta Packing's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

- Cal/OSHA's Emergency Action Plan - Title 8 CCR ?3220

- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Emergency Action Plans - Title 29 CFR ?1910.38

- Cal/OSHA's Process Safety Management [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 8 CCR ?5189(n)

- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management [Emergency Planning and Response Requirements]- Title 29 CFR ?1910.119(n)

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4.5 ?2765.1-2765.2

- USEPA Risk Management Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 40 CFR ?68.95

- California Hazardous Materials Business Plan (HMBP) [Emergency Response Plans and Procedures] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4 ?2731



Strategically, we will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 



Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.



1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Delta

Packing has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Delta Packing continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.

By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Delta Packing's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Delta Packing's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.



Delta Packing has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.



In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Delta Packing has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.



For the future, Delta Packing now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Delta Packing employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Delta Packing will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
